wikipedia_page.main: James Fleming (1830–1908) was an Irish clergyman of the Church of England, public speaker and fund-raiser. A canon of York Minster, he became chaplain in ordinary to Queen Victoria and Edward VII, and was a close friend of the British royal family.

response: * James Fleming (rugby union, born 1987), Scottish rugby union player
* James Fleming (Nova Scotia politician) (1741–1839), farmer, businessman and politician from Nova Scotia
* James Fleming (Ontario politician, Peel) (1839–1902), lawyer and member of the Canadian House of Commons representing Peel
* James Fleming (Ontario politician, York West) (born 1939), former broadcaster and member of the Canadian House of Commons representing York West
* James Fleming, 7th Baron Slane (bef. 1442–1492), member of the Irish Parliament and sheriff of County Meath
* James Fleming, 4th Lord Fleming (c. 1530–1558), Lord Chamberlain of Scotland
* James Fleming (author) (born 1944), author of the "Charlie Doig" thrillers
* James Fleming (British Army officer) (1682–1751), British major-general
* James Fleming (priest) (1830–1908), clergyman of the Church of England

response: Weston was born on 26 March 1840 in London, the daughter of a barrister. In 1851 she, her mother and siblings were living in Weston, Bath.Agnes Weston in the 1851 England Census. Census Returns of England and Wales, 1851. Kew, Surrey, England: The National Archives of the UK (TNA): Public Record Office (PRO), 1851. via Ancestry.com paid subscription site: 1851 England Census (database on-line). Provo, UT, USA: Ancestry.com Operations Inc, 2005. Accessed December 2019. She was influenced from her teenage years onward by the Reverend James Fleming, curate of St Stephen, Lansdown, in the parish of Walcot, Bath (1855–1859), an advocate for total abstinence, lack of ritual in religious expression, and living one's faith through good works.

response: The Public Reading Society founded in the 1850s was the vehicle of Charles John Plumptre, a barrister who turned to the teaching of elocution. Charles Sulley, editor of the Ipswich Express, was credited with starting the penny reading movement in Suffolk during the 1850s. A short history was given in the 1865 standard reading collection edited by Joseph Edwards Carpenter. The Rev. James Fleming of Bath was also credited as the "father of the penny-reading movement", for his numerous public readings.
